department: DANM - Digital Arts and New Media

courses.DANM 50 — Gayming: An Introduction to Qu:
Course: DANM 50 — Gayming: An Introduction to Queer Theory in Games
Credits: 5
Description: Students learn the basics of queer theory and how to apply it to game design and play. They engage with a number of queer games both physical and digital as well as learn how to apply queer theory to their own design and style of play.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 51 — Queer and Trans Art Practices:
Course: DANM 51 — Queer and Trans Art Practices
Credits: 5
Description: Beginning with the liberation movements of the 1960s, course traces the work of queer and trans artists over the decades that followed. Students consider representations of queer life amid the Gay Liberation Movement of the 1970s, underground experimental film and New Queer Cinema, art of the AIDS crisis and the activist art collectives of ACT UP, and millennial artists working today across digital and fine arts. One of the driving questions of our explorations will be, how do these artists undo and rework concepts like identity, medium, and form? (Formerly Queer and Trans Art History Since Stonewall.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 52 — Altering the Digital Image and:
Course: DANM 52 — Altering the Digital Image and Creative Art Practices
Credits: 5
Description: Throughout the 10-week course, students are guided through the principles and elements of digital design and digital filters for editing as a creative approach to image-making, template building, poster design, collage, and color theory methodology. Students are encouraged to develop a portfolio of digital images based on their primary interests. The course is focused on aesthetics, color theory, and design as the central common theme.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 130 — Embodiment in New Media Art:
Course: DANM 130 — Embodiment in New Media Art
Credits: 5
Description: Engages the topic of embodiment within new media art theory and practice. Focus is on embodiment within performance, time-based, electronic, and new media arts practice. Students produce a final paper and artistic project on the topic. Lower-division undergraduates may enroll with permission of instructor.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment restricted to juniors and seniors.
courses.DANM 132 — Literary Games: The Intersect:
Course: DANM 132 — Literary Games: The Intersection of Writing and Play
Credits: 5
Description: Hands-on course surveying the thriving micro-genres in the neutral zone between games and literature. Students read, play, and author stories that couldn't exist on a printed page. Interactive fiction, algorithmic poetry, and brand-new experiments.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 133 — Introduction to Electronics a:
Course: DANM 133 — Introduction to Electronics and Physical Computing
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces electronics using the open-source Arduino platform. Learn how to build interactive circuits through hands-on tutorials. In a workshop environment, students acquire the technical skills required to create electronic artwork. No previous experience required.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 134 — Hacking for Artists: Experime:
Course: DANM 134 — Hacking for Artists: Experimenting with Digital Media
Credits: 5
Description: Hacking is the modification, reconfiguration, and reuse of computer code or hardware to create new functionality. Course encourages a hands-on approach to digital-media creation including the basics of computer programming and hacking techniques. No programming experience required.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 135 — Kinematics: Motion and Machin:
Course: DANM 135 — Kinematics: Motion and Machine Art
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the history of machines. Kinetic art is presented including: animatronic puppetry, balance mobiles, light compositions, logic and mechanical art, interactive sculpture, and resonance cymatics. Students utilize automation techniques to create art projects using a modular set of gears, linkages, cams, belts, and springs. Discussion of technological advances in the field of kinetic art and its impact on society.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 136 — Mapmaking for Environmental A:
Course: DANM 136 — Mapmaking for Environmental Activism
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the basic principles of geographic analysis and visual communication through mapmaking. Projects focus on environmental issues, and class discusses best practices for distributing information and communicating ideas.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 138 — Procession: Where Sculpture M:
Course: DANM 138 — Procession: Where Sculpture Meets Costumes Meets Performance
Credits: 5
Description: Teaches techniques to animate sculptures, such as wearables/body art, mobility, puppetry, sound, light, or projection. Covers building techniques and how to incorporate individual creativity in a collaborative setting to create a common theme for the procession.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 140 — Introduction to 3D Printing,:
Course: DANM 140 — Introduction to 3D Printing, Laser Cutting, and More
Credits: 5
Description: Learn to design functional objects, sculpture, and other digitally inspired forms in a variety of 3-D applications (Cinema 4-D, Maya, AutoCad, Rhino, SketchUp), then produce those models as physical objects with a variety of rapid prototyping methods including additive 3-D printing, CNC milling, vacuum forming, and laser cutting.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 141 — Introduction to Soft Interact:
Course: DANM 141 — Introduction to Soft Interaction: Fiber Arts and Reactive Technologies
Credits: 5
Description: Students learn to create interactive artwork through the combination of fiber arts and reactive technology. Course explores electronic art that is worn or touched, and discovers new developments in eTextiles that allow for this interaction.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 143 — Projects in Ecological Art:
Course: DANM 143 — Projects in Ecological Art
Credits: 5
Description: By investigating topics related to water in California, students produce works of digital and new media art that engage with environmental issues and the local community.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 144 — Surveillance and Digital Desi:
Course: DANM 144 — Surveillance and Digital Design
Credits: 5
Description: How can we understand surveillance through a digital arts lens? What are the connections between surveillance and race, gender, sexuality, and class? How can we challenge oppressive surveillance policies in creative ways? In this interdisciplinary course students critically engage with the topic of surveillance by interacting with important scholarship and artworks in digital arts and surveillance studies. Knowledge on the subject deepened through class discussions, submission of written reflections, and group creative responses to the course content.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 146 — Game Design in Participatory:
Course: DANM 146 — Game Design in Participatory Performance
Credits: 5
Description: Students get a grounding in the fundamentals of game design and character driven performance. Meetings focus on a combination of understanding current practice across various styles of interactivity, and practice of participatory performance culminating in a short group performance with participatory elements.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 147 — Introduction to Queer Game St:
Course: DANM 147 — Introduction to Queer Game Studies
Credits: 5
Description: Examines writing about Queer gamesâboth academic and non-academicâas well as contemporary Queer games. Students write an essay that synthesizes Queer theory and game studies and also answer a few short questions about each reading. A midterm draft of the game and a final prototype are required, as well as a post-mortem as a final paper. Throughout the course, students gain experience in looking critically at pieces of digital media art, creating short video games, and reading Queer theory as well as game studies writing.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 148 — Introduction to Game Prototyp:
Course: DANM 148 — Introduction to Game Prototyping
Credits: 5
Description: Introductory course on the process of game prototyping. By playing seminal works made by oppressed creators in the industry, and performing close readings of their mechanics, students build games literacy and learn how to use free and low-cost tools to make personal, fluid work. Engages in the creation of games on a weekly basis, while thinking about the political, artistic, and cultural values the work embodies. Throughout this process, students discuss different models of prototyping, iterate on game design procedure, and reflect deeply on their finished work.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 149 — Intro to Games Culture:
Course: DANM 149 — Intro to Games Culture
Credits: 5
Description: Survey course on game communities. Games are a globally entrenched medium, with communities of players gathering together both online and offline. Students map how different communities navigate status and mastery, study online fan groups, and document their interactions to gain a better understanding of the dynamics at play. Investigates how marginalized communities can be left behind in the search for mastery, and as a class students create tools for intervening in our own communities when exclusionary trends are seen.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.DANM 199 — Tutorial:
Course: DANM 199 — Tutorial
Credits: 5
Description: Independent digital arts and new media research project under the guidance of a digital arts and new media faculty member or other faculty. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. Enrollment restricted to juniors and seniors.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 199F — Tutorial:
Course: DANM 199F — Tutorial
Credits: 2
Description: Independent digital arts and new media research project under the guidance of a digital arts and new media faculty member or other faculty. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 201 — Recent Methods and Approaches:
Course: DANM 201 — Recent Methods and Approaches to Digital Arts and Culture
Credits: 5
Description: Students examine methods and approaches to research and writing in digital art and new media, while exploring key theories concerning technology, art, and culture. Focus is on the interaction between digital technologies and socio/cultural formations.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.DANM 202 — Dialogues and Questions in Di:
Course: DANM 202 — Dialogues and Questions in Digital Arts and Culture
Credits: 5
Description: Students engage in dialogues at the intersection of theory and practice with the goal of producing a pre-thesis proposal and essay. Readings and seminar discussions inform the development of project proposals and essays, which theoretically contextualize students' work.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.DANM 203 — Professional Development for:
Course: DANM 203 — Professional Development for the Arts
Credits: 5
Description: A professional art practices practicum that focuses on researching opportunities and developing practical strategies and skills to ensure success outside an academic environment.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.DANM 210 — Project Design Studio:
Course: DANM 210 — Project Design Studio
Credits: 5
Description: Students work on the design of individual projects by developing project proposals, budgets, proof of concept design documents and/or prototypes and exploring tools, technologies, programming languages, hardware, software, and electronics techniques relevant to their projects.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.DANM 211 — Critique:
Course: DANM 211 — Critique
Credits: 5
Description: First-year digital arts and new media graduate students are required to present work-in-progress based on the projects developed in earlier courses and during the current quarter in individual studio critiques with the instructor as well as in group critiques.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.DANM 212 — Thesis Proposal:
Course: DANM 212 — Thesis Proposal
Credits: 0
Description: First-year digital art and new media graduate students work on the development and completion of their thesis-project proposal and abstract under the supervision of the program chair and their thesis committees.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to DANM students.
courses.DANM 215 — MFA Exhibition Production:
Course: DANM 215 — MFA Exhibition Production
Credits: 5
Description: Second-year digital arts and new media graduate students work with faculty curator/coordinator to develop thesis projects specifically for the group exhibition context. Students contribute to exhibition design and collateral materials while studying the unique presentation and curatorial challenges of new media.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.DANM 216 — Digital Bodies:
Course: DANM 216 — Digital Bodies
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the appearance, form, and theoretical status of the human body/political subject in online art. Focuses on representations of race and gender, family resemblances, and local communities, as well as the political and colonial metaphors of spatial interaction operating on the World Wide Web. Visual representations of bodies that take the form of avatars, advertising, robots, and anime studied in their contextual usage.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students. Upper-division undergraduates may enroll with permission of instructor.
courses.DANM 219 — Introduction to Electronics f:
Course: DANM 219 — Introduction to Electronics for Artmaking
Credits: 5
Description: Intensive introduction to electronic devices used in artmaking, providing hands-on experience with sensors, motors, switches, gears, lights, simple circuits, microprocessors, and hardware storage devices to create kinetic and interactive works of art. Students are billed a materials fee of $118.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.DANM 220 — Introduction to Programming f:
Course: DANM 220 — Introduction to Programming for the Arts
Credits: 5
Description: Covers aspects of computer programming necessary for digital art projects. Students learn to manipulate digital media using program control for installations, presentations, and the Internet. No prior programming experience required.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.DANM 221 — Mathematics and the Arts:
Course: DANM 221 — Mathematics and the Arts
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the role of mathematics in the arts since the computer revolution with an emphasis on chaos, fractals, and symmetry. Covers abstract animation and algorithmic music, including the history of leading innovators and techniques from 1950 to the present. Student projects explore the creative process today using cutting-edge technologies.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 227 — Projected Light in Performanc:
Course: DANM 227 — Projected Light in Performance
Credits: 5
Description: Exploration of projected light in performance and art. The history of lighting as art is covered in a hands-on demystifying format from the shadow of a bare light bulb to the latest in automated and projection equipment and techniques.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students. Juniors and seniors may enroll with permission of instructor.
courses.DANM 233 — The Object as Interface:
Course: DANM 233 — The Object as Interface
Credits: 5
Description: Combination theory and studio-based exploration into the role of the object in real and virtual space. Provides a broad conceptual and theoretical examination of issues relating to object-making on a physical and dematerialized plane.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.DANM 241B — Modern Art: Cubism to Pop:
Course: DANM 241B — Modern Art: Cubism to Pop
Credits: 5
Description: A history of the visual arts from the 1910s to the 1960s beginning in Europe and moving to the United States. Follows key movements of modern art while emphasizing the social, political, and philosophical events that inform it. Students cannot receive credit for this course and HAVC 141B .
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students in digital arts new media, film, music, social documentation, theater, or visual studies.
courses.DANM 250A — Art and Science:
Course: DANM 250A — Art and Science
Credits: 5
Description: Students investigate new methods in art and science collaboration through faculty-initiated projects to solve real-world problems and produce outcomes of substantial artistic and scientific value. (Formerly Collaborative Research Project Group: Art and Science.)
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 250B — Socially Engaged Art:
Course: DANM 250B — Socially Engaged Art
Credits: 5
Description: Students join digital methods with community-media activism through faculty-initiated projects to facilitate a culture of participation and social engagement. (Formerly Collaborative Research Project Group: Socially Engaged Art.)
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 250C — Performance and Embodiment:
Course: DANM 250C — Performance and Embodiment
Credits: 5
Description: Students investigate performance and embodied experience as profound sources of understanding and communication through faculty-initiated projects, pushing the limits of human identity, affect, empathy, and expression. (Formerly Collaborative Research Project Group: Performance and Embodiment.)
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 250E — Collaborative Research Proje:
Course: DANM 250E — Collaborative Research Project Group: Experimental Play
Credits: 5
Description: Three-quarter, collaborative-research, project group encompasses a range of faculty-initiated projects that investigate computer games and related forms to engage audiences, make arguments, tell stories, and shape social space through creation of new games and through reading and playing related works.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 250F — Film, Moving Image Installat:
Course: DANM 250F — Film, Moving Image Installation, and Curatorial Lab
Credits: 5
Description: Workshop investigating moving and still images to create visual and sonic languages for production, exhibition and installation. Core faculty Mark Nash and Isaac Julien invite students to participate in ongoing projects as well as present and discuss their own work. Established artists, film makers and curators are also invited to present their work to the group. (Formerly offered as Research Group: Isaac Julien Studio Lab.)
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 250G — Research Group: Isaac Julien:
Course: DANM 250G — Research Group: Isaac Julien Studio Lab - London Quarter
Credits: 15
Description: Research group course focusing on research and production of Isaac Julien's and Mark Nash's moving image and curatorial projects. Course takes place in the Isaac Julien Studio in London. Students encouraged to develop and prototype their own projects and thesis work. Course includes case studies, workshops, guest speakers, seminar discussions, and site visits. Outside of class students work on independent projects, as well as projects in the Isaac Julien Lab alongside staff. Enrollment is by instructor permission and open to DANM graduate students and graduate and Ph.D. students in other project groups or programs upon application.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 250I — Interdisciplinary Arts Produ:
Course: DANM 250I — Interdisciplinary Arts Production Lab
Credits: 5
Description: The IAPL is open to musicians, visual artists, programmers, designers, writers, dancers, actors, or artists of any discipline. The course/lab addresses various topics regarding interdisciplinary, cross-cultural, and multimedia practices, including performance practices, collaborative art-making, improvisation and listening, music and video performance software, networked performance, distribution, and online broadcasting. Each Interdisciplinary Arts Production Lab series involves the creation and development of special project and artworks that are presented either at the end of the term or at the conclusion of the academic year. Students cannot receive credit for this course and MUSC 150Z
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 254I — Empirical Approaches to Art:
Course: DANM 254I — Empirical Approaches to Art Information
Credits: 5
Description: Reading and practice in empirical methods, as applied to the study of music, visual art, multimedia production, and performance arts. Topics include semiotics, critiques of empiricism, cultural determinants and contingents of perception, the psychophysics of information, sensory perception (visual and auditory), memory, pattern recognition, and awareness. Students apply existing knowledge in the cognitive sciences to a developing creative project, or develop and conduct new experiments.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 280 — Seminar in Digital Arts and N:
Course: DANM 280 — Seminar in Digital Arts and New Media
Credits: 5
Description: Weekly seminar covering topics of current research in digital arts and new media. Focuses on student presentations and seminar participation.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 281 — Special Topics in Digital Art:
Course: DANM 281 — Special Topics in Digital Arts and New Media
Credits: 5
Description: This hybrid theory/practice course examines the social implications of emerging technologies and cultural practices, with a focus on how artists and other producers engage with them in a critical manner that reveals their inner logics and/or deploys them for alternative purposes.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 297 — Independent Study:
Course: DANM 297 — Independent Study
Credits: 5
Description: Independent digital arts and new media research project under the guidance of a digital arts and new media faculty member or other faculty with approval of adviser. Project includes readings, research, and a written report. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. Enrollment is restricted to graduate students. Maximum 10 credits.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 297G — Independent Study:
Course: DANM 297G — Independent Study
Credits: 3
Description: Independent digital arts and new media research project under the guidance of a digital arts and new media faculty member or other faculty with approval of adviser. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. Enrollment is restricted to graduate students. May be repeated for a maximum 6 credits.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.DANM 299 — Thesis Research:
Course: DANM 299 — Thesis Research
Credits: 5
Description: Students carry out a master's of fine arts thesis in digital arts and new media research, under the guidance of a thesis committee. The thesis will be an arts project with digital documentation accompanied by a written paper discussing the student's preparatory research as well as the theoretical significance of the project. Enrollment is restricted to graduate students. Maximum 10 credits.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.CMPM 290J — Playable Media:
Course: CMPM 290J — Playable Media
Credits: 5
Description: Focuses on media, such as computer games, that invite and structure play. Work includes building and critiquing a series of prototypes; studying major examples in the field; and discussing both theoretical and practice-oriented texts. Enrollment by permission of instructor. Enrollment restricted to graduate students.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.CMPM 290P — Topics in Computational Cine:
Course: CMPM 290P — Topics in Computational Cinematography
Credits: 5
Description: Focuses on discussion of recent advances in visual storytelling in graphical environments. Major topics covered are: intelligent camera control, shot-compositions, lighting design, interactive storytelling, and computational techniques associated with these applications. Class consists of in-class discussions and student presentations of research papers and a final student project.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.CSE 265 — Human-Computer Interaction:
Course: CSE 265 — Human-Computer Interaction
Credits: 5
Description: Theory and hands-on practice to understand what makes user interfaces usable and accessible to diverse individuals. Covers human senses and memory and their design implications, requirement solicitation, user-centered design and prototyping techniques, and expert and user evaluations. Individual research project. Interdisciplinary course for art, social science and engineering graduate students. Students cannot receive credit for this course and CSE 165 .
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.THEA 251 — Graduate Student Production:
Course: THEA 251 — Graduate Student Production
Credits: 5
Description: Participation by a graduate student in a departmental production of a play, dance concert, or other performance event under supervision of the Instructor-of-Record. Rehearsals culminate in public performance. Enrollment is restricted to graduate students and determined by audition with the instructor and in consultation with the director of graduate studies.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 290A — Research Methods for Perform:
Course: THEA 290A — Research Methods for Performance and Practice
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the emergent professional artist-scholar into the discipline of what is called practice-as/practice-based/practice-led research in performance and new media. Explores the rationales, conceptual frameworks, and perils that underpin research based on the researcher's own creative endeavors, and that enable the researcher to place their own practice within larger artistic and theoretical paradigms in a written document. (Formerly offered as Text Analysis.)
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students in theater arts.
courses.THEA 294 — Future Stages:
Course: THEA 294 — Future Stages
Credits: 5
Description: Working in an experimental theater with access to new performance technologies, course explores how cross-media practice can expand on basic theatrical relationships in new and culturally relevant ways.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
